Posts.Title: Homestretch, chin-up fell, what gets you through? chemo072 mccarroll

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 08:35PM figsgirls wrote: Yep, it's the Taxol. My lashes actually all fell out a few weeks after I finished the Taxol. But they grew in really quickly. Then a few months later they all fell out again. And again! They seem to have stabilized now, almost a year since I finished chemo! My eyebrows are still looking pretty bad, though. I wonder if they'll ever be normal again or if I'll be filling them in with brow powder for the rest of my days.
Posts.Title: Eyelashes tomatojuice ksmerrill

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2007 10:22PM figsgirls wrote: I am using something called Anastasia Brow Powder, that I got at Sephora. It's great. It comes with stencils you hold up to where your brow is (or is supposed to be) and then brush on the powder. It comes with a wax that you then dab on to set the powder. My daugther says it looks totally natural and she is brutally honest so if they looked fake she would definitely tell me! My brows only thinned a little on AC but then fell out a lot on Taxol. The same with my lashes. Now, after tx 9 of 12, the upper lashes are almost all back, lower ones are coming in slowly, but those brows are really poky!! My head hair is coming in steadily, and my pubic hair is starting to return! Donna
Posts.Title: Eyelashes and Eyebrows jdg1 jdg1

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 02:56PM figsgirls wrote: My hair grew in very, very grey after chemo. I had it colored 2 1/2 months after I finished chemo and it took perfectly and did not damage my hair.
Posts.Title: Hair Color Mistake Kara Kara

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2007 08:34PM figsgirls wrote: Writing this as I sit here eating pretzel rods with mustard and thinking the pretzels are not salty enough. I am so very glad to read that others are experiencing the same thing I am! I have been noticing that I crave salt. The other day I was eating potato chips and I kept looking at them really closely, even read the ingredients list, because they tasted like they were unsalted! Also I'm really into pickles. How about dill pickle flavored potato chips?? While on the A/C I was really into olives, but now on Taxol I can't stand the sight of them. I think I associate them with the crappiness I felt on A/C. I don't have a metallic taste but I do think my tastebuds are dulled.  I, too, lost a significant amount of weight about a year before my dx - about 35 pounds through Weight Watchers. I have gained about 12 of it back since my first surgery 5/9/07 and it is driving me crazy as well.
Posts.Title: Craving crunchy salty chips after chemo trigeek kagaines

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2008 04:46AM figsgirls wrote: Hey Margaret, I ran during chemo (well it was sort of running - quite slow with some walk breaks...). I bought these things called buffs to wear on my head. You can configure them several different ways - like a beanie or a cap with some of the fabric coming out the back to protect your neck from the sun. Sometimes I would wear them under a baseball cap. I like them because I can still use them now that tx. is over. (If you ever watched "Survivor", these are the things they wore on the show. I will NOT be wearing mine as a tube top, however! lol) They are effective at keeping sweat out of your eyes, which I found to be an issue especially once I started losing eyebrows and lashes in addition to my hair. I ordered them online. Good luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: head cover while playing tennis pacmom pacmom

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2008 05:22AM figsgirls wrote: I have 2 dogs and 3 cats and they were the best antidote to everything bad about chemo. My onc never even mentioned anything about them. DH does the litter boxes and poop patrol in the yard anyway. And I washed my hands a lot. Pets rock.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2008 11:12AM figsgirls wrote: No problems bathing and mine was only sore for a couple of days. Sometimes it itches but it's nothing I can't tolerate. It does make the chemo and blood draws WAY easier. At my place, the nurses would spray the port with the numbing stuff, so I never felt anything. One thing I hate is that my port shows quite a lot. It looks like I have a 2 liter bottle top under my skin, and you can see the whole outline of the tube that runs from it up to my neck. Most unattractive. I finished chemo 11/26 so although my onc. likes to have his patients keep their ports in for a year after chemo, mine is coming out on Thursday when I have my swap surgery. Good luck.
Posts.Title: I.V Port kissta Cathy-CA

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2007 01:50PM figsgirls wrote: And you're not being selfish for wanting DH there the first time! It is new and can be scary. Besides, as my wise daughter pointed out when I began losing my hair and my husband wanted to shave his head in solidarity but I didn't want him to: Men want to fix things. They can't fix your BC. But they can do stuff like shave their head, and it makes them feel a tiny bit less helpless. She said I should let him shave his head. The same with having your DH accompany you to chemo. I know my DH feels helpless sometimes, and it's hard on him too. So he shaved his head and wears his BC pink ribbon and sat with me through the first chemo. So don't feel guilty - you might be helping him feel like he's doing something.

Posts.Title: questions for those done w/chemo bluewillow karen1956

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2007 10:23AM figsgirls wrote: While on A/C, I ate a lot of noodles and pasta and drank a lot of flavored seltzer water because tap water didn't appeal to me. I also went through a phase where I ate a lot of olives. Now, unfortunately, I can't stand the sight of any of those foods! Prior to chemo I loved those foods. I recall someone posting to be careful about eating foods during chemo that you loved before chemo, because you might associate the food with the bad feeling of chemo and it will turn you off. Well, it happened to me. I have been craving pizza for weeks and have been afraid to eat it for that reason. Now that I've had my 3rd of 12 Taxols and don't have any stomach issues, I think I may try the pizza.......... I did drink a lot of orange juice and eat a lot of frozen fruit pops, both of which I'm still OK with now. Cool project, by the way.
Posts.Title: What are you eating while on chemo bonny1963 figsgirls

Posts.Content: figsgirls wrote: Don't be sad! The other day I read an article in the newspaper about how it is now chic for women to have gray or white hair! The article pointed to famous women like Jamie Lee Curtis and Helen Mirren (I think that is her name), and oh no...chemo brain...the actress who played the magazine editor in "The Devil Wears Prada", I can't remember her name! Who knew we chemo ladies were so cutting edge?? Funny because I saw this article on a day when I was lamenting that my stubble appears to be primarily gray, and everyone says you can't color your hair for a while after chemo. Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2007 01:41PM figsgirls wrote: My DH came with me for my first A/C also. I kind of went back and forth about having him there also. The tx went fine and I felt fine afterward, so for tx 2-4 I drove myself. The nurses are great and I bring stuff to read and crossword puzzles to keep me busy. Lots of times there is chatter and joking going on between the nurses and the people receiving treatment, so it's a pretty relaxed environment. For the Taxol I was told I was required to have a ride because they would be giving me Benedryl, so my daughter took me. She went and got us lunch, then we chatted and she got some reading done for school while I did a puzzle. The nurse said I would fall asleep because of the Benedryl, but I didn't. Just felt a tiny bit spacey. By the time we left, I felt like I could drive myself. But then again, I don't want to be like a drunk person who thinks they are OK to drive but in reality they're not so I'll probably continue to have DD take me. Donna
Posts.Title: Your first chemo... Dragonfly92127 garnetann

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2007 01:36AM - edited Sep 11, 2007 01:40AM by figsgirls I feel your pain, Harley! I'm 42 and pre-bc I'd been coloring my hair for at least 15 years. This past spring I asked my hair stylist how gray I was and she said about 50%. I am afraid of how much there will be when it grows back in now. The "Look Good, Feel Better" booklet advises not coloring your hair until it grows in fully. That's a long time! And yes, it was Meryl Streep. Thanks for jogging the chemobrain.

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2007 07:46AM figsgirls wrote: Also, sometimes I find that my family (specifically my mother) responds well if I tell them very clearly what is and isn't helpful. Sometimes I have to remind my mother that I need to think about ME first. Yesterday I had my consult with the oncologist and it was really hard emotionally. While I was at the appointment, my mother called and left a message to invite me over because my brother had arrived in town for the week. I was not in an emotional state to be around anyone, so I didn't call her back until later in the afternoon and then I tried to explain. Her response was, "Your brother was disappointed, he really wants to see you". So I had to (gently) tell her that I couldn't make myself responsible making my brother feel better about my cancer. I think she understood. Sometimes I think she just doesn't think and of course she has no experience having a daughter with cancer. But it is frustrating none the less!

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2007 05:31AM figsgirls wrote: Now I feel better! I've been trying to use email a lot. I guess part of my issue is that I never liked talking on the phone all that much. So now I won't feel badly if I tell the people who are not super close to me that email is better at least for now. I know that is what my husband has chosen to do. And for those who don't have email, well they are mostly my older relatives and my parents gladly disseminate information to them. Thanks ladies. This forum is really SO HELPFUL!!

Posts.Content: figsgirls wrote: Since I was diagnosed 4/11, it seems that our phone rings constantly! Family, friends, colleagues of my husband and me....they call because they care and want to express their concern...but it seems that if we answer every call we would spend every waking moment talking about my breast cancer. Caller ID helps, and many times we let the calls go to the answering machine and return them if/when we are up to it. Sometimes I feel like I'm being rude if I don't answer or call back right away, though, because as I said I know people just mean well and are concerned. How do you handle this part of having cancer? Thanks! Donna Diag. 4/11/07 ILC 4.3cm 1/14 nodes ER+/PR+ Her2-. Lump., bilat.mast. 4AC 12 Taxol, Tamox. Implant recon. Log in to post a reply
